This a is a lovely and very short (30 second) article. Written from a Belgian legal perspective but still applicable and I think this line is king: ‚û° [C]ompanies not covered by the CSDDD as such may still be affected as a subsidiary or supply chain business partner of an in-scope company ‚¨Ö That's my big warning to all companies with a presence in Europe over the coming years, expect to be affected (read PLAN FOR) by CSDDD regardless of if you're IN SCOPE or NOT. https://lnkd.in/d4krMdYH

One year after the introduction of the German Act on Corporate Due Diligence Obligations in Supply Chains (LkSG), we can draw a positive balance. The law marks a significant step towards sustainable supply chains and responsible corporate governance in Germany. As of January 1, 2024, it applies to companies with more than 1,000 employees and a site in Germany. In our latest article, we analyse the progress made, reflect on successes and challenges and take a look at the future of these affected companies. (Link to the article in the comments) #supplychain #lksg #corporateresponsibility #ESG #sustainability #duediligence

‚ùá * WE SUPPORT THE #CSDDD* The EU's Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD) has generated broad support from a wide range of stakeholders, including large companies, SMEs, civil society organizations, trade unions and many more. The fact that it's been hard to keep track of the different pro-CSDDD statements is telling of people's desire to hold companies accountable for wrongdoings in their value chain. üîî I can therefore highly recommend this newly launched website hosting different expressions of support by academics, businesses, unions, experts in the field, etc.: https://lnkd.in/dguEHeGb üîé Please have an extra look-out for the political statement by the Swedish parliament's business committee, which signals that the Swedish government stands behind the latest compromise text, despite initially abstaining in COREPER. Notwithstanding the gaps and weaknesses in the latest agreement, Sweden's support shows that even the most obstructive Member States can be convinced that this is what is needed to advance responsible business conduct. ‚úè Tomorrow, 24 April, MEPs are voting in plenary on the latest compromise. If adopted, the file will go once again to COREPER on 15 May and finally to the Council of Ministers on 24 May. As always, to be continued...
